attributes.title: Transitional supports for youth with mental illness and problematic substance use entering higher education: A scoping review protocol
attributes.description: The objective of our review is to synthesize the literature on post-secondary transition interventions for youth/young adults with mental illness and/or problematic substance use.

summary.value:
Background: Transition-aged youth (TAY), ages 16 to 24, with mental illness and/or problematic substance use may experience unique challenges in making the transition from secondary to post-secondary education. As secondary and post-secondary education funding becomes more resource constrained and allocated based on institutional performance outcomes, a clear understanding of emerging best practices for transitioning TAY with mental illness/problematic substance use into higher education is critical. The objective of our review is to synthesize the literature on post-secondary transition interventions for youth/young adults with mental illness and/or problematic substance use.

Methods: Arksey and O'Malley's original scoping review framework will be utilized with guidance from the Joanna Briggs Institute. A structured search of MEDLINE (OVID), CINAHL, ERIC, SocINDEX, and PsycINFO will be conducted with the support of a librarian specialist following the development of a strategic search strategy. Studies to be included will: (i) be published in English (ii) involve youth ages 16-24 with mental illnesses and/or problematic substance use, and (iii) provide primary research evidence on an intervention/strategy/technique for transitioning TAY with mental illness/problematic substance use into higher education. A data extraction tool will be developed and piloted on a subset of studies. 

Discussion: Addressing the research questions should reveal the breadth of current knowledge regarding practices and strategies for facilitating the successful transition of TAY with mental illness/problematic substance use into the post-secondary education system. Understanding what has been trialed, implemented and validated for the transition of TAY with mental illness/problematic substance use into post-secondary across various countries will be of extraordinary use to post-secondary institutions looking to support incoming students with mental health needs. An understanding of best practices for the successful transition of TAY with mental illness/problematic substance use into post-secondary education could have a significant impact for meeting new performance criteria for public funding, as well as identify areas where addition research is needed.

registration_responses.summary:

An understanding of best practices for the successful transition of TAY with mental illness/problematic substance use into post-secondary education could have a significant impact for meeting new performance criteria for public funding, as well as identify areas where addition research is needed.

attributes.title: Equations based on anthropometric measurements for body fat or body density prediction in children and adolescents: A scoping review protocol

q1.value: Equations based on anthropometric measurements for body fat or body density prediction in children and adolescents: A scoping review protocol

q2.value: Matheus Cerqueira, Paulo Henrique Ribeiro Fernandes Almeida, Leonardo Matheus Teixeira Resende, Manuel Sillero-Quintana, Diego Augusto Santos Silva, Fernanda Karina dos Santos, João Carlos Bouzas Marins, Paulo Roberto Santos Amorim

q3.value: This project intends to identify anthropometric equations to predict body fat or density in children and adolescents, using in vitro or in vivo techniques as reference methods and to analyze methodological aspects related to the development of equations that used skinfold measurements.

q4.value: Which body fat or body density prediction equations based on existing anthropometric measurements for children and adolescents? What methodological details are described for the development of anthropometric equations using skinfolds?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: In this scope review, the searches will be conducted in: EMBASE, MEDLINE (PubMed), The Cochrane Library, SCOPUS, Web of Science, CINAHL, SportDiscus and the Latin American and Caribbean Health Sciences (LILACS). The search strategy will include terms related to: child, adolescent, anthropometry, body composition, and methods of body composition evaluation. In order not to lose studies, a manual search will be carried out in the references of the selected studies and systematic reviews and studies in the gray literature in the Brazilian Digital Library of Theses and Dissertations.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Two reviewers will independently review the titles (Phase 1) and abstracts (Phase 2) of all studies identified by the searches, and will discuss and address any discrepancies arising with a third reviewer. Complete studies (Phase 3) considered potentially relevant for inclusion after discussion between the reviewers will then be obtained and two independent reviewers will evaluate them for eligibility, with any disputes being resolved by consensus or by discussion with a third reviewer. Data will be extracted from the studies chosen to be included by only two reviewers using a standard form, prepared previously. Any disagreements will again be resolved by consensus or discussion with a third reviewer. This process will be performed using Rayyan, a Web application designed to assist in this step of the review studies.

q13.value: Studies that include children and adolescents between five and 19 years old.

question.value: Body fat or body density prediction equations based on existing anthropometric measurements for children and adolescents.
Only descriptive statistics will be used.

attributes.title: How social media is being used to research the experience of mourning: a scoping review protocol

summary.value: This scoping review proposes to map how social media data is being used in research about the experience of mourning.

registration_responses.summary: This scoping review proposes to map how social media data is being used in research about the experience of mourning.

attributes.title: Preoperative anxiety reduction psychoeducation program in adults: a scoping review protocol

summary.value: This is the record for the scoping review entitled " Preoperative anxiety reduction psychoeducation program in adults: a scoping review protocol". There are no prior records.

registration_responses.summary: This is the record for the scoping review entitled " Preoperative anxiety reduction psychoeducation program in adults: a scoping review protocol". There are no prior records.

q1.value: Dr.A.R.Pradeep kumar, Dr.Nivedhitha Malli Sureshbabu, Professor Velmurugan Natanasabapathy, mohamed jubair

q2.value: Vertical root fracture is one of the complications seen in endodontically treated teeth. It is a longitudinally oriented fracture of the root usually directed in the buccolingual plane.Fracture usually initiates in the root and may extend coronally. Diagnosis is difficult in early stages. Early diagnosis of VRF and subsequent extraction/radisection leads to preservation of bone in that area. we hypothesised that Vrf can be detected by surgical exploration/extraction compared to CBCT

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: PubMed, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, LILACS and google search were searched from January 1990 to December 2019 for eligible studies. A manual search of the Journal of Endodontics; Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, Oral Pathology, Oral Radiology and Endodontics; International Endodontic Journal was performed.  Quality Assessment of Diagnostic Accuracy Studies-2 (QUADAS-2) was employed to assess the quality of the included studies.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Databases searched-PubMed, Cochrane, Google Search
Search Terms- VRF, Vertical root fracture, CBCT, Diagnosis, Surgical exploration
years/time periods covered- from 1990 to dec 2019
which is better method for diagnosing vrf
All the statistical analyses were performed using Meta-Disc 1.4 version software and Meta-analyst software

registration_responses.q1: Dr.A.R.Pradeep kumar, Dr.Nivedhitha Malli Sureshbabu, Professor Velmurugan Natanasabapathy, mohamed jubair

It is a longitudinally oriented fracture of the root usually directed in the buccolingual plane.Fracture usually initiates in the root and may extend coronally. Diagnosis is difficult in early stages. Early diagnosis of VRF and subsequent extraction/radisection leads to preservation of bone in that area. we hypothesised that Vrf can be detected by surgical exploration/extraction compared to CBCT

attributes.title: Decay and Retention of Training Effects in the Simulated Child Sexual Abuse Interviews
attributes.description: This research will examine the decay of improved interview skills by the Avatar Training and its retention by boosters using professionals who are in charge of interviewing children in Japan.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Decay and Retention of Training Effects in the Simulated Child Sexual Abuse Interviews

sample.value: We will recruit 40 participants aiming for 20 participants per condition.

analyses.value:
[Hypothesis 1: Check for success of randomization to booster schedules]
Planned analyses for dependent variable 1-6
 - Regarding the result of the first session, we will conduct two-factor mixed ANOVAs with the schedule of booster and time as independent variables for each of the dependent variables except for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions.
Planned analyses for dependent variable 7
 - Regarding the result of the first session, we will conduct t-tests with the schedule of booster as independent variables for the proportion of correct conclusions.
Expected effects for dependent variable 1-6
 - Regarding the result of the first session, only the main effects of time will be significant for all six dependent variables.
Expected effects for dependent variable 7
 - Regarding the result of the first session, no significant difference will be obtained for the proportion of correct conclusions.
 
[Hypothesis 2: Check for decay in performance over time]
Planned analyses of dependent variable 1-6
 - Within the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, we will conduct one-factor ANOVAs with the last/first interviews (the last interviews of the first training session and the first interviews of the 1 month booster session and the 6 months booster session) as an independent variable for each of the dependent variables except for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions. Multiple comparisons between the last interview of the first session and the first interviews of second and third sessions using Holm's method (Holm, 1979) will be conducted for all these dependent variables.
 - Within the 6 months only booster schedule, we will conduct t-tests with the last/first interviews (the last interviews of the first training session and the first interviews of the 6 months booster session) as an independent variable for each of the dependent variables except for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions.
Planned analyses of dependent variable 7
 - Within each schedule, we will conduct Chi-squared tests with the last/first interviews (the last interviews of the first training session and the first interviews of the 1 month booster session and the 6 months booster session) for the dependent variable. Pairwise Chi-squared tests between the last interview of the first session and the first interviews of the second and third sessions will be conducted for all these dependent variables.
 - Within the 6 months only booster schedule, we will conduct a Chi-squared test with the last/first interviews (the last interviews of the first training session and the first interviews of the 6 months booster session) for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions.
Expected effects of dependent variable 1-6
 - Regarding the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, the main effects of the last/first interviews will be significant for all six dependent variables. Multiple comparisons will show that the last interviews of the first training session have significantly better questioning skills and interview quality than the first interviews of the 1 month booster session and the 6 months booster session. 
 - Regarding the 6 months only booster schedule, t-tests will show that the last interviews of the first training session have significantly better questioning skills and interview quality than the first interviews of the 6 months booster session.
Expected effects of dependent variable 7
 - Regarding the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, Chi-squared tests will show the significant results. Pairwise Chi-squared tests will show that the last interviews of the first training session have a significantly higher proportion of the correctness of conclusions than the first interviews of the 1 month booster session and the 6 months booster session. 
 - Regarding the 6 months only booster schedule, Chi-squared test will show that the last interviews of the first training session have a significantly higher proportion of the correctness of conclusions than the first interviews of the 6 months booster session.
 
[Hypothesis 3: Check for retention by the 1 month booster]
Planned analyses of dependent variable 1-6
 - Regarding the result of the 6 months booster sessions, we will conduct t-tests with the schedule of booster as an independent variable for each of the dependent variables in the FIRST interview except for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions.
Planned analyses of dependent variable 7
 - Regarding the result of the 6 months booster sessions, we will conduct a Chi-squared test with the schedule of booster for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions in the FIRST interview.
Expected effects of dependent variable 1-6
 - t-tests will show that the FIRST interviews of the 6 months booster session of 1 month + 6 months booster schedule have significantly better questioning skills and interview quality than that of 6 months only booster schedule.
Expected effects of dependent variable 7
 - Chi-squared test will show that the FIRST interviews of the 6 months booster session of 1 month + 6 months booster schedule has a significantly higher proportion of the correctness of conclusions than that of 6 months only booster schedule.
 
[Hypothesis 4: Check for enhancement by the 1 month booster]
Planned analyses of dependent variable 1-6
 - Regarding the result of the 6 months booster sessions, we will conduct t-tests with the schedule of booster as an independent variable for each of the dependent variables in the LAST interview except for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions.
Planned analyses of dependent variable 7
 - Regarding the result of the 6 months booster sessions, we will conduct Chi-squared tests with the schedule of booster for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions in the LAST interview.
Expected effects of dependent variable 1-6
 - t-tests will show that the LAST interviews of the 6 months booster session of 1 month + 6 months booster schedule have significantly better questioning skills and interview quality than that of 6 months only booster schedule.
Expected effects of dependent variable 7
 - Chi-squared test will show that the LAST interviews of the 6 months booster session of 1 month + 6 months booster schedule have a significantly higher proportion of the correctness of conclusions than that of 6 months only booster schedule.
 
[Hypothesis 5: Check for faster re-learning]
Planned analyses of dependent variable 1-6
 - Within the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, we will conduct one-factor ANOVAs with the difference between first and second interviews as an independent variable for each of the dependent variables except for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions. Multiple comparisons between sessions using Holm's method (Holm, 1979) will be conducted for all these dependent variables.
 - Within the 6 months only booster schedule, we will conduct t-tests with the difference between first and second interviews as an independent variable for each of the dependent variables except for the proportion of the correctness of conclusions.
Expected effects of dependent variable 1-6
 - Regarding the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, the main effects of the session will be significant for all six dependent variables. Multiple comparisons will show that the first training session has significantly smaller improvement of questioning skills and interview quality than the 1 month booster session and the 6 months booster session. 
 - Regarding the 6 months only booster schedule, t-tests will show that the first training session has significantly smaller improvement of questioning skills and interview quality than the 6 months booster session.

outliers.value: Data of participants who do not conduct 4 interviews for each session will be excluded from analyses.

dependent.value:
Questioning skill will be measured using the following measurement: 
(1) Number of recommended questions asked by the interviewer 
(2) Number of not recommended questions asked by the interviewer 
(3) Proportion of recommended questions asked by the interviewer 
 
Interview quality will be measured using the following measurements: 
(4) Number of relevant details elicited from the avatars 
(5) Number of irrelevant details elicited from the avatars 
(6) Number of wrong details elicited from the avatars 
(7) Correctness of conclusions as to whether the interviewed avatars were abused in the second and subsequent interviews
 
The increase of (1) and (3), and a decrease of (2) represents an improvement in interviewing skills. 
Increases of (4), (5), and (7), and a decrease of (6) represent an improvement of the interview quality. 
 
Each participant will conduct 4 interviews with feedback on outcome and question-type and behavioral modeling in each session. Each interview will last a maximum of 10 minutes, and participants will ask questions verbally to the avatar to elicit information for making a conclusion regarding the alleged CSA for the avatar.
Outcome feedback: A description of what actually happened in the case 
Question-type feedback: Explanations about 2 recommended questions and 2 not recommended questions asked by the interviewer 
Behavioral modeling: Watching videos of good and bad interviews for abused and non-abused cases after reading learning points

conditions.value:
This study has a 2x4 mixed design based on the following 2 factors:
 - Schedule of booster: after 6 months only vs. 1 month + 6 months (between-subjects)
 - Time: From 1st to 4th interviews (within-subjects) 
 
Participants will be randomly assigned to the following two conditions:
 - Condition 1: Participants will conduct interviews, and receive a booster after 6 months (i.e., Participants will conduct 2 sessions)
 - Condition 2: Participants will conduct interviews, and receive boosters after 1 month and 6 months (i.e., Participants will conduct 3 sessions)

hypothesis.value:
(1) In the first session of Avatar Training, no difference between two booster schedules (after 6 months only and 1 month + 6 months) is found in the improvement of questioning skills and interview quality (Check for success of randomization to booster schedules).
(2) For those in the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, the last interviews of the first training session have better questioning skills and interview quality than the first interviews of the 1 month booster session and the 6 months booster session. Similarly, for those in the 6 months only booster schedule, the last interviews of the first training session have better questioning skills and interview quality than the first interviews of the 6 months booster session (Check for decay in performance over time). 
(3) In the last session (6 months after the first session) of Avatar Training, the first interviews of the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule shows better questioning skills and interview quality than those of the 6 months only booster schedule (Check for retention by the 1 month booster).
(4) In the last session (6 months after the first session) of Avatar Training, the last interviews of the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule shows better questioning skills and interview quality than those of the 6 months only booster schedule (Check for enhancement by the 1 month booster).
(5) In the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, the changes in questioning skills and interview quality between the 1st and 2nd interviews in the first training session are smaller than the changes between the 1st and 2nd interviews in the 1 month booster and 6 month booster sessions. Similarly, in the 6 months only booster schedule, the changes in questioning skills and interview quality between the 1st and 2nd interviews in the first training session are smaller than the changes between the 1st and 2nd interviews in the 6 months booster session (Check for faster learning by the previous session).
* Avatar Training: simulated Child Sexual Abuse interviews using avatars

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Decay and Retention of Training Effects in the Simulated Child Sexual Abuse Interviews

This study has a 2x4 mixed design based on the following 2 factors:

registration_responses.hypothesis:
(1) In the first session of Avatar Training, no difference between two booster schedules (after 6 months only and 1 month + 6 months) is found in the improvement of questioning skills and interview quality (Check for success of randomization to booster schedules).
(2) For those in the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, the last interviews of the first training session have better questioning skills and interview quality than the first interviews of the 1 month booster session and the 6 months booster session. Similarly, for those in the 6 months only booster schedule, the last interviews of the first training session have better questioning skills and interview quality than the first interviews of the 6 months booster session (Check for decay in performance over time). 
(3) In the last session (6 months after the first session) of Avatar Training, the first interviews of the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule shows better questioning skills and interview quality than those of the 6 months only booster schedule (Check for retention by the 1 month booster).
(4) In the last session (6 months after the first session) of Avatar Training, the last interviews of the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule shows better questioning skills and interview quality than those of the 6 months only booster schedule (Check for enhancement by the 1 month booster).
(5) In the 1 month + 6 months booster schedule, the changes in questioning skills and interview quality between the 1st and 2nd interviews in the first training session are smaller than the changes between the 1st and 2nd interviews in the 1 month booster and 6 month booster sessions. Similarly, in the 6 months only booster schedule, the changes in questioning skills and interview quality between the 1st and 2nd interviews in the first training session are smaller than the changes between the 1st and 2nd interviews in the 6 months booster session (Check for faster learning by the previous session).
* Avatar Training: simulated Child Sexual Abuse interviews using avatars

attributes.title: Analyzing the Role of Painful and Provocative Events on the Acquired Capability for Suicide and Impulsivity
attributes.description: Testing the Painful and Provocative Events Scale (PPES) as a formative measurement model.

q1.value: Analyzing the role of Painful and Provocative Events on the Acquired Capability for Suicide and Impulsivity

q3.value: Though there is evidence that painful and provocative events (PPEs) are associated with suicidal thoughts and behaviours (STBs; Bender, Gordon, Bresin, & Joiner, 2011), the painful and provocative events scale (PPES) has reported poor psychometric properties (Brown et al., 2018). Therefore, the purpose of this study is to analyze the PPES with a formative measurement model. This will test the content and convergent validity of the PPES and provide insight on what variables PPEs are associated with.

q4.value:
If higher exposure to painful and provocative events leads to a higher ACS, then higher PPES scores will be associated with higher scores on fearlessness about death and pain tolerance.

We predict that PPES scores will be higher when negative urgency and sensation seeking scores are higher.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a cross-sectional study design that will use a Fixed-Weight Redundancy Model (FWRM) approach (Chiu, Hsu, Lowry, & Liang, 2018). In this approach, there are two steps: 1) Estimating the weights of the formative indicators using a redundancy analysis model. 2) Fixing the weights obtained from step 1 for the formative indicators and estimating a structural model.

Step 1:
The first redundancy analysis model will have 25 observed variables that will load onto a formative construct whose disturbance term is fixed to 0. The formative construct will be linked to a global and reflective measure of the construct (i.e., acquired capability). 

The second redundancy analysis model will have 25 observed variables that will also load onto a formative construct whose disturbance term is fixed to 0. The formative construct will be linked to two latent variables that are reflective measures of sensation seeking and negative urgency. 

Step 2:
The weights obtained from step 1 will be used to estimate two structural models. These structural models will test whether acquired capability predicts suicidal intent, NSSI, and other variables relevant to suicidal thoughts and behaviours.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data are archival and all of it has been collected prior to analyses. The data was collected as a part of a previous project entitled “Identifying Factors Associated with Future Self-Directed Violence Within a Sample of Mississippi National Guard Personnel.” The authors pledge that analysis of the data has not been analyzed prior to registration.

question.value: Subjects were collected from a National Guard base in Hattiesburg, Mississipi. Participants were elligible if they were ever enrolled in the U.S. military. They could be at the military base doing drills or returning home from deployment.

q13.value: The dataset contains 953 participants that were enrolled in the U.S. military at the time of data collection. After excluding participants (see exclusion criteria), we will use the all of the remaining data.

q14.value: The full sample after excluding invalid cases will be used to maximize power. After excluding participants, we expect to have around 500 - 700 valid cases.

question.value:
The formative indicators that will form/define the composite variable are items from the Painful and Provocative Event Scale (PPES). The 25-item version was used. The PPES asked participants, "Please answer the following questions for any time in the past," where participants answered how many times they had experienced several events (e.g., "Have you gone skydiving?"). The PPES contains a scale from 1-5, 1 being "Never" and 5 being "More than 20 times." 

The first redundancy analysis model contains two outcome variables:
1. Perceived pain tolerance. This was measured with a subset of questions on the ACSS. Participants were asked, "Please read each item below and indicate to what extent you feel the statement describes you,' where participants responded on a Likert-type scale from 0 being "Not at all like me" to 4 being "Very much like me." One item from the ACSS will represent pain tolerance: 4 ("I can tolerate more pain than most people"). The description of each item can be found in the attached document of the ACSS.

2. Fearlessness About Death (FAD). This was measured with a subset of questions on the ACSS. The following items from the ACSS will represent FAD: 7 (“The fact that I am going to die does not affect me”), 8 ("The pain involved in dying does not frighten me"; reverse scored), 10 (“I am very much afraid to die”), 11 (“It does not make me nervous when people talk about death”), 13 (“The prospect of my own death arouses anxiety in me”; reverse-scored), 14 (“I am not disturbed by death being the end of life as I know it”), and 19 (“I am not at all afraid to die”). This is consistent with Ribeiro et al's (2014) findings that these 7 items formed a replicable factor structure that is substantively related to fearlessness about death.

The second model contains two outcome variables:
1. Sensation seeking. This refers to one's tendency to seek out thrilling experiences. The was measured with the Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance, Sensation Seeking, Positive Urgency, Impulsive Behavior Scale (UPPS-P). Participants were asked, "Below are a number of statements that describe ways in which people act and think. For each statement, please indicate how much you agree or disagree with the statement." Participants responded on a Likert-type scale, with 1 being "Agree strongly" to 4 being "Disagree strongly." The sensation seeking subscale will be used.

2. Negative urgency. This refers to one's tendency to act rashly in the face of negative emotions. The same instructions that were used to measure this variable as they were for sensation seeking. The negative urgency subscale will be used.

data.name: ACSS items from Ribeiro et al. (2014).doc

extra.selectedFileName: ACSS items from Ribeiro et al. (2014).doc

question.value:
Sum scores will be used to represent Fearlessness About Death in the redundancy analysis model, with the exception of perceived pain tolerance, which only contains one item.

Scores for each individual item on the sensation seeking and negative urgency subscale will be used to identify the sensation seeking and negative urgency constructs in the second rendundancy analysis model.

Hypothesis #1 (Model 1): We will use a redundancy analysis model to analyze our results. In this model, 1 formative construct will be formed by the items on the PPES. The formative construct will be linked to a reflective measure of acquired capability (i.e., the ACSS-FAD subscale and pain tolerance as measured by the ACSS). 

Hypothesis #2 (Model 2): A second redundancy analysis model will be fitted to the data. In this model, 1 formative construct will be formed by the items on the PPES. The formative construct will be linked to latent variables that predict item scores on the negative urgency subscale and the sensation seeking subscale in the UPPS-P. 

Both models will use covariance-based structural equation modelling (CB-SEM) with maximum likelihood estimation.

Following Chiu et al's (2018) procedure. We will use the following criteria to redesign the PPES so only the most relevant items to the formative construct are included:
- Items will be considered for deletion if their path coefficient is too low (ideally, PC > .8)
- Items will be considered for deletion if there's a multicolinearity problem. If the variance inflation factor is greater than 3.3 then the item may be problematic.
- Weights and bivariate correlations that are statistically nonsignificant will be considered for deletion.

Due to the predominant use of multiple indicator multiple cause (MIMIC) models in formative measurement models, these models will be compared to the redundancy analysis models to see if there are any major discrepancies or differences. Several nested models of hypotheses 1 and 2 will be fitted to the data:
Model 3: Hypothesis #1 will also be tested with a MIMIC model that has one latent variable and two reflective indicators (ACSS-FAD subscale scores and pain tolerance scores on the ACSS). A chi-square difference test between model 1 and model 3 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

Model 4: Hypothesis #2 will be tested by fitting a model that has two latent variables (one latent variable corresponding to negative urgency and the second corresponding to sensation seeking). A chi-square difference test between model 2 and model 4 will be used to see if the models are significantly different from each other.

q21.value:
Good model fit will be determined by the following criteria:

Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA): < .06
Comparative Fit Index (CFI): > .95
Tucker Lewis Index (TLI): > .95
Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR): < .08
Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC): < .08
 
Using Burnham and Anderson's (2003) criteria for interpreting Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) scores:
ΔAIC < 2 -> substantial evidence for the model.
3 > ΔAIC 7 -> less support for the model.
ΔAIC > 10 -> the model is unlikely.
Where ΔAIC is the model with the difference between the best model and each other model in the set.

q23.value:
Listwise deletion will be applied to PPES items with missing data. Listwise deletion will also be applied to the pain tolerance item on the PPES. 
Predictive mean matching (PMM) imputation will be applied to all other scores (i.e., ACSS-FAD and UPPS-P scores).

q24.value:
After estimating the measurement models for the PPES, the weights of the formative indicators obtained from these models will be applied to the structural model estimations. This part will be exploratory, as we aim to explore the relationship among the PPEs, acquired capability, and other variables relevant to suicidal thoughts and behaviours. Structural models may be informed by theory (e.g., using the interpersonal psychological theory of suicide to see if perceived burdensomeness, thwarted belongingness, and acquired capability predict suicide intent or suicide attempts). However, other variables such as distress tolerance may also be analyzed in relation to PPES scores. 

It is possible that not all PPEs meaningfully contribute to greater ACS or impulsivity. Consequently, new models will be tested that drop items on the PPES that do not have significant or high correlations with the formative construct. Model fit of these newly developed models will be assessed.

q25.value:
References
Bender, T., Gordon, K., Bresin, K., & Joiner, T. (2011). Impulsivity and suicidality: The mediating role of painful and provocative experiences. Journal of Affective Disorders, 129(1-3), 301–307. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jad.2010.07.023

Brown, S., Roush, J., Marshall, A., Mitchell, S., & Cukrowicz, K. (2018). A Psychometric Investigation of the Painful and Provocative Events Scale: Moving Forward. Archives of Suicide Research, 22(4), 628–643. https://doi.org/10.1080/13811118.2017.1392914

Chiu, C., Hsu, J., Lowry, P., & Liang, T. (2018). Solving the Interpretational-Confounding and Interpretational-Ambiguity Problems of Formative Construct Modeling in Behavioral Research: Proposing a Two-Stage Fixed-Weight Redundancy Approach. Journal of the Association for Information Systems, 19(7), 618–671. https://doi.org/10.17705/1jais.00504

attributes.title: Projectivity, at-issueness and prior with factive and non-factive predicates

q2.value:
Tonhauser & Degen (2019, XPRAG talk) found that the more content is taken to be a priori true, the more likely it is to project. In that work, we collected prior probability ratings and projection ratings from different groups of participants. We found that the prior probability of content predicts projection of the content of the complement of 20 predicates, including both factive and non-factive ones. In this experiment, we collect prior probability ratings and projection ratings from the same participants (i.e., in a within-participant design).

Hypothesis
We hypothesize that a participant's rating of the prior probability of content predicts the participant's projection rating: the higher the prior probability, the more projective.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Predicate and prior are within-participant factors. For each participant, a set of 20 content/fact combinations are created. In the prior block, the prior probability of the content given the fact is rated; in the projection block, the content/fact combinations are combined randomly for each participant with the 20 predicates and the projectivity of the content is rated. It is a block design: projection and prior are measured in separate blocks, with block order randomized by participant. Half of the stimuli are low-prior items, half are high-prior items (as established in a separate norming study), sampled randomly by participant.

q7.value: Each participant rates the projectivity of the content of the complement of each of the 20 clause-embedding predicates given a fact about the content, as well as the prior probability of each content given the fact. The predicates are randomly combined with one of the 20 complement clauses for each participant, and each content is randomly combined with a high or low prior probability fact. The order of the projectivity and prior blocks is randomized by participant, as is the order of the 20 stimuli in each block.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 300 participants (US IP addresses, at least 99% of prior HITS approved) are recruited on Amazon's Mechanical Turk platform. Each participant is unique (as ensured by the use of UniqueTurker). They are paid $1.80 and told the experiment takes about 9 minutes. They are told that they will assess the likelihood of events in one part and read questions that people ask to evaluate what these people meant in a second part. On a pre-screening page, Turkers are presented with a statement that one named person says to another. Turkers are excluded from participating if they fail to type the name of the second person into a box 3 times.

q11.value: We will recruit 300 participants to provide judgments on projectivity and prior of the contents of the complements of the 20 clause-embedding predicates given a prior (high or low) fact about the content.

q12.value: Based on sample size for the projection experiment of the XPRAG 2019 talk (300 participants).

question.value: The clause-embedding predicates are manipulated (20 levels) as well as the prior probability of the content of the complement (2 levels: high, low). We also manipulate the complement clauses (but this manipulation is not of theoretical interest).
Projectivity and prior of the contents are measured via the certainty and likelihood diagnostic used in the experiments reported on in the  XPRAG 2019 talk.
Analyses are described here: https://github.com/judith-tonhauser/attitude_preds_projection
See analysis files in the GitHub repo: https://github.com/judith-tonhauser/attitude_preds_projection

q18.value: See analysis files in the GitHub repo: https://github.com/judith-tonhauser/attitude_preds_projection

q19.value: See analysis files in the GitHub repo: https://github.com/judith-tonhauser/attitude_preds_projection

q20.value: See analysis files in the GitHub repo: https://github.com/judith-tonhauser/attitude_preds_projection

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Alternate analyses (likely to be reported in supplementary materials)
1. We will also report analyses for our hypotheses that rely on uninformative priors (as opposed to the priors informed by prior experiments.)

2. We will run a frequentist logistic regression for the main analysis (H1) and report a one-sided p-value for the mechanism - no_mechanism contrast.

Exploratory Analyses

1. We will report proportions standing for every level of the interaction and compare posterior distributions for each level of each factor.

2. We may run more complex mediation models to explore how psychological distance and ratings of how frightening the message was influence the effect of the mechanism message on standing.

3. We will explore the relationships between all ratings variables (see https://osf.io/xpekq/ for the survey and relevant variables) and how they relate to standing as well as how they are affected by the manipulations.

sample.value:
Based on Bayesian precision analyses, 300 participants per condition (totaling 1,200 participants) should yield a 95% Credible Interval for an odds ratio (for the comparison of mechanism versus no mechanism messages) of approximately +/- 0.35.

Furthermore, a frequentist power analysis with a one-sided test of mechanism versus no mechanism with an effect size of OR ~ 1.4 alpha = .05 and power ~.8, yields an N ~ 300. 

Script for power analyses were completed here - https://osf.io/3xkqe/ (alongside prior specifications).

analyses.value:
Analysis H1: 
We will run a full factorial Bayesian logistic regression (2 (Mechanism, No Mechanism) X 2 (Outcome, No Outcome)) estimating whether they reported standing up during the experiment for 30-seconds. We will estimate the odds ratio for standing rates when the mechanism message is present versus absent. We expect to see a probability of direction (i.e., the percentage of the posterior). We will use priors from previous pilot studies (see https://osf.io/3xkqe/ (i.e., PROJECT Standing_Mechanism_v_Outcome_pilot_models.R) for prior specifications.)

Analysis H2: 
We will run a full factorial Bayesian ordinal regression estimating how their ratings of how frightening the message is, changed in each condition. We will compare posterior distributions for each level of the interaction term (see PROJECT Standing_Mechanism_v_Outcome_pilot_models.R for prior specifications.)

Analysis H3: 
We will run a full factorial Bayesian linear regression estimating how participants' ratings of how psychological distance the messages was perceived, changed in each condition. We will compare posterior distributions for each level of the interaction term (see PROJECT Standing_Mechanism_v_Outcome_pilot_models.R for prior specifications.)

Analysis H4:
We will run a Bayesian logistic regression estimating the relationship between standing and their ratings of psychological distance.

Analysis H4:
We will run a Bayesian logistic regression estimating the relationship between standing and participants' ratings of how frightening the message was.

outliers.value:
Exclusions: 
Only observations of participants who completed the entire study will be included. 
We will exclude participants who didn't complete the attention check question (in a rating task at the end of the study, one item saying "...please choose Strongly Agree").

dependent.value:
We have three main dependent variables: 
1. Self-reported information whether a participant wants to stand up for 30-seconds during the experiment (they are asked if they want to stand for 30-seconds, if they say yes -- the next screen will not allow them to continue for 30-seconds) [Yes/No]
2. Rating of how frightening the message was (1Not at all to 7Extremely)
3. Rating of psychological distance (0 (Near) -100 (Far))

conditions.value:
Participants will randomly be assigned to one of four conditions: 2 (outcome vs. no outcome) x 2(mechanism vs. no mechanism)
Participants will be presented with a message about the importance of standing up during work hours. The "Outcome" message describes the long-term health consequences of sitting for too long (i.e., cancer, diabetes), whereas the "Mechanism" message describes the physiological effects that occur in the moment, while sitting for too long (which are associated with the long-term health consequences). Participants will either receive the outcome message, the mechanism message, both messages combined, or a control message in which they receive a message about health researchers recommendations for how often to stand up as well as a statistic on how much time office workers spend sitting per week. (All conditions will include the control message.)

hypothesis.value:
H1: We will see a higher proportion of participants standing up when the mechanism message is present as compared to when it is absent.

H2: Participants receiving the outcome plus mechanism message and the outcome only message will rate the message as the most frightening, followed by the mechanism message alone, then the control message. 

H3: All messages will be perceived as less psychologically distant than the control message

H4: Smaller psychological distance will be associated with a greater proportion standing.

H5: Greater frightened ratings will be associated with a greater proportion standing.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Project Standing-up Messaging
registration_responses.other:
Alternate analyses (likely to be reported in supplementary materials)
1. We will also report analyses for our hypotheses that rely on uninformative priors (as opposed to the priors informed by prior experiments.)

2. We will run a frequentist logistic regression for the main analysis (H1) and report a one-sided p-value for the mechanism - no_mechanism contrast.

Exploratory Analyses

1. We will report proportions standing for every level of the interaction and compare posterior distributions for each level of each factor.

2. We may run more complex mediation models to explore how psychological distance and ratings of how frightening the message was influence the effect of the mechanism message on standing.

3. We will explore the relationships between all ratings variables (see https://osf.io/xpekq/ for the survey and relevant variables) and how they relate to standing as well as how they are affected by the manipulations.
registration_responses.sample:
Based on Bayesian precision analyses, 300 participants per condition (totaling 1,200 participants) should yield a 95% Credible Interval for an odds ratio (for the comparison of mechanism versus no mechanism messages) of approximately +/- 0.35.

Furthermore, a frequentist power analysis with a one-sided test of mechanism versus no mechanism with an effect size of OR ~ 1.4 alpha = .05 and power ~.8, yields an N ~ 300. 

Script for power analyses were completed here - https://osf.io/3xkqe/ (alongside prior specifications).

q1.value: Clare Conry-Murray, Thomas Joseph Harrison, Mackenzie Gillen

q2.value: Freshmen and sophomores will drink more than junior and seniors, especially when they are told that drinking n campus is common.  When they believe drinking is uncommon, there will be no age differences.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2(age) x 2(how common is drinking on campus)

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: I am posting a link on social media for participants to follow so they can fill out my survey.  The survey includes demographics, a measure of year in school, and two between-subject conditions indicating that drinking is either common or uncommon on my campus.  Participants will be assigned to groups a based on the last digit of their phone number.

q11.value: Ideally, I will have 20 per between subject group (IV 1--commonness of drinking) and (IV2-- age), for a total of 80.  I expect to collect data from 40-100 participants.

q12.value: My professor said to get 20 per cell for between subjects effects.  Power analysis.

q13.value: I plan to stop collecting data once I have at least 25 per cell or 100 total.

question.value:
Commonness of drinking-- 2 levels
1. The Hawk survey incoming freshmen who started at SJU in the Fall of 2019 and found that students drink 80% on the weekend.
2. The Hawk survey incoming freshmen who started at SJU in the Fall of 2019 and found that students drink 20% on the weekend.

IV: Gender-- male and female
DV: How likely are you to drink on a weekend when you're at school?
I will not split my variable at the medium. I will not add up any variables.
ANOVA to test for interaction between age and commonness of drinking
